episodes.synopsis: David Attenborough explores why mammals, including humans, are the most successful and diverse animals on the planet.
episodes.title: A Winning Design

episodes.synopsis: Mammals that hunt insects shared the planet with the dinosaurs, but when the giant reptiles disappeared, these creatures conquered new territory.
episodes.title: Insect Hunters

episodes.synopsis: Heavily armoured, indigestible and even poisonous, plants pose problems for some of our biggest predators.
episodes.title: Plant Predators

episodes.synopsis: Distinguished by their large, powerful incisors, rodents eat a diet of mostly seeds and roots. Among them are rats, mice and the dexterous squirrel.
episodes.title: Chisellers

episodes.synopsis: David Attenborough delves into the lives of carnivorous mammals and the animals they prey upon for sustenance.
episodes.title: Meat Eaters

episodes.synopsis: Because they are able to eat a varied diet, omnivorous "opportunists" such as bears and raccoons manage to thrive in almost any environment.
episodes.title: Opportunists

episodes.synopsis: Unique mammals have evolved by forgoing land for life at sea. Among those featured are dolphins, seals and whales.
episodes.title: Return to the Water

episodes.synopsis: Special light is shed on the arboreal monkeys and primates that eat, play and sleep within the trees.
episodes.title: Life in the Trees

episodes.synopsis: Human beings are the so-called top mammals on the food chain. Human physical characteristics and social habits are compared with other mammals.
episodes.title: Food for Thought

video.title: The Life of Mammals
video.synopsis: David Attenborough hosts this in-depth examination of mammals, from the smallest shrew to the biggest whales and the most advanced primates.
